Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2008 11:07PM Gitane wrote: Rayne, The oncotype test will give you an estimated probability of recurrence, the likelihood you would benefit from chemo based on primarily the proliferation rate of your tumor cells, the levels of ER and PR that gives you some information about the likelihood of responding to endocrine therapy.  All said, though, nobody really knows because we're all different.  Even high ER and PR do not guarantee response to endocrine therapy.  Even high proliferation scores do not guarantee a response to chemo.  I had a very low proliferation rate, an intermediate recurrence score, and had a great response to chemo.   Even a low recurrence score does not mean you won't have a recurrence. We have to make decisions we can live with.

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2008 10:02PM Gitane wrote: Sites of breast cancer recurrence • Local recurrence – Cancer reappears at the original tumor site.  • Regional recurrence - Cancer has spread past the breast and underarm (axillary) lymph nodes. Regional recurrences can occur in the chest muscles, in the lymph nodes under the breastbone, between the ribs, above the collarbone and surrounding the neck.  • Contralateral recurrence - Cancer has spread to the other breast. • Distant recurrence (metastasis) – Cancer has spread to other parts of the body.

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2011 06:26PM - edited Aug 1, 2011 06:56PM by Gitane In the NSABP B-31 study,  available blocks were tested centrally with FDA-approved Her2 FISH assay.  Surprisingly, there was no association between Her2 gene copy number and benefit from trastuzumab (interaction p=0.60)  Even patients with normal gene copy numbers appeared to benefit from Trastuzumab treatment (RR- 0.40) This finding was studied, restudied and scrutinized extensively by many experts in many ways.  Independent study results clearly suggest that the benefit may not be restricted to Her2 positive patients as currently defined. They don't know if current clinical essays are not precise enough or if there are other molecular determinants of response besides Her2.  The current thinking is that the latter is true.  Another possibility may be that there there are micromets that are Her2+ in patients with Her2-  tumors.  This has been demonstrated by several investigators in small-scale studies that measured Her2 in circulating tumor cells.  I am sorry, but I don't have those studies, but I'm sure your oncologist can find them. Analysis of NSABP B-31 outcomes did not find any genes or sets of genes or clinical variables (like age, ER, size, nodes, etc.) that predicted benefit, but they found that women with ER+, 1-3 positive nodes, and t-size <2cm didn't seem to benefit statistically, even those that were Her2+. There is an experimental assay, the NanoString-based HER2 assay, that the NCI is recommending be used in the NSABP B-47 protocol.  It has identified a set of genes, measures their mRNA, and seems to identify those that may benefit from trastuzumab better than other measures.  I believe that this either is or was written up in The New England Journal of Medicine, but I haven't looked for it yet. I was able to get all this info by googling NSABP B-47, then downloading a PDF document (30 pages long) I found on page 3.  It's called "Final Progress Report for Research Projects Funded by Health Research Grants" about research done between 2/08 and 12/09, then presented to NCI in 2/10.   I know this is long, but if it will help you I'd be very happy,  Hugs, G.  Edited to add this great discussion I found. http://podcast.researchtopractice.com/podcast/pdf/bcu/BCUTT1_09.pdf Starts talking about Her2 and B-31 down on page 9 with lots of references/history for your oncologist.

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2009 08:35PM Gitane wrote: Hi Phoenixsmom,  In some ways our diagnosis is similar.  I had more than one tumor, in fact many tumors, spread over an 8 cm area of my left breast.  This is a bit different than an 8 cm tumor, at least that was how it was explained to me.  I also had some DCIS.  I was told that DCIS combined with ILC is not that common.  Chemo did not get rid of my DCIS.  Unlike you, I didn't have a complete response in the invasive part; there were residual scattered nests of cells.  I had a SNB before my chemo; there were individual tumor cells in one node, a few small clusters < 2mm in one node, and a micromet of 1mm in one node.  In all 9 nodes were removed, the other 6 were clear.  No more nodes were removed after chemo.  I am telling you all this because my oncologist did not recommend I have radiation.  He said in my case it would be a local control issue and not affect distant recurrence.  I got a second opinion, and was told it was a hot issue among oncologists and really was my decision.  The risk would be potential damage to the heart, lungs, and ribs.  I also had a bilateral mastectomy with saline implants.  Since the professional opinions I was getting leaned strongly toward the benefit being small and risks being huge, I decided against rads.  I'm 4 years out now.  I guess time will tell if I decided correctly.

A while back I copied this from another poster.  I'll put it here, although I've never tried it.  Hopefully someone who knows more than I do will be along to help. How to post a picture on BC.ORG   Go to: http://register.photobucket.com/ Register....Its free.  Then when you login there will be a prompt to Upload Images and you click on choose files. Browse to where your picture is on your computer.  After your picture is uploaded to photobucket you will see the picture, and several options below the picture as follows:  Email & IM Direct Link HTML Code IMG Code  Click on Direct Link and that copies the picture to the clipboard.  Then when you come back to the post a reply window at Breast Cancer.org and you are ready to paste that picture in....click on the little green tree up by the smiley emoticons and where it says image url put your cursor in there and just hit [control c] and and it will automatically paste in the url in from photobucket.  Give this a whirl.....it is not that hard but might take you some trial and error.  Anyway...give that a try.

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2008 10:31PM Gitane wrote: emursen, Ask for the MRI. Other screening technologies are not nearly as reliable, especially if you have dense breasts.  Ask to have the MRI done at a good facility with someone reading it who has experience with breast MRI. This will help you to know more about why those microcalcs are there before they do the biopsy.  Biopsies are useless if they aren't fishing in the right spot, or if the cancer they may be fishing for is not a tight solid tumor.  Many times cancer can be diffuse and the biopsies that are not MRI guided might miss it altogether.  You want as much info as you can get right now.

Posts.Content: May 30, 2008 02:47PM Gitane wrote: Hi Janene, I'm just popping in to say I think your tumor being Progesterone Receptor positive makes it very probable that it is Estrogen Receptor positive, also. Even if it isn't, it is still very likely that you will be given an endocrine (hormone) therapy, because the Progesterone Receptor being positive indicates that the estrogen receptor pathway is still functional and endocrine therapy will probably work. The estrogen receptor status can be confirmed and if there is any doubt retested. You will not need a blood test, this is all done on the tumor sample in the pathology lab. I don't know if mistakes like these are made often. I don't think they are, but sometimes the communication between labs, doctors, and patients isn't what it should be. Isn't it frustrating that you and your treating physicians are made to wait? The waiting seems to be the hardest thing because it delays getting on with treatment. In any case, I think the results will indicate you can benefit from endocrine therapy and that's good.

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2009 09:40PM Gitane wrote: My onc said after my chemo and bilat mast that he thought I shouldn't have rads.  He said there was a chance it would help me avoid local recurrence.  He also said there was a chance it would damage my ribs, heart, and/or lungs since they would be radiating the chest wall.  I had tissue expanders at the time, but the significance of that on reconstruction was never discussed, I don't remember why.  Seems like I should have been asking more questions about that but I didn't.   I got a second opinion at UCLA.  That onc said that getting rads in my situation was controversial.  He felt it was really impossible to weigh the pros and cons as too much was still being researched and unclear.  I also heard the 5 cm size as a cut off.  My tumor was multifocal over an 8 cm area.  Well, I didn't have rads, we'll see, I guess, if I made a good decision.

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2009 11:58PM Gitane wrote: I found this little blurb about rads in a 2007 Medscape article so I thought I'd just post it. http://cme.medscape.com/viewarticle/560671_7 Postmastectomy Radiation Therapy 2007 Do all patients require postmastectomy radiation therapy (PMRT) after neoadjuvant chemotherapy? In the International Journal of Radiation Oncology, Huang and colleagues will soon present data suggesting that the MD Anderson Hospital prognostic index can be applied to mastectomy patients. Dr. Buchholz reported the risk for locoregional recurrence following neoadjuvant chemotherapy and mastectomy at 19% of patients with local failure of pCR vs 28% of patients with residual cancer, suggesting that selection of patients for PMRT cannot be based on response alone.[22] With the addition of PMRT, the recurrence rate in patients with stage III disease declined from 20% to 9%, but did not significantly decrease in patients with stage II disease (which declined from 9% to 5%).[23] Among patients treated with mastectomy in NSABP B-18, none of whom received PMRT, the recurrence rate was 0% in patients with pCR but 10.5% in patients with residual cancer in which the cancer had not metastasized to the lymph nodes and 20.3% in those in which it had. However, most of these patients had T1 and T2 tumors,[24] suggesting that initial stage, degree, and location of residual disease should be used in determining the need for PMRT after neoadjuvant chemotherapy. I hate stats, but it looks like they have learned a lot about rads in the years after my diagnosis.  I bet they're much better at giving the rad treatments safely, too.

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2009 09:25PM - edited Jul 2, 2009 09:29PM by Gitane Hi Sea,  From what you have written here about the find needle biopsies: 1.   There are some cancer cells in the under arm area, in the tail of the breast.  They are probably in a lymph node.  They don't say how much they saw, just "cells" which doesn't tell you much about size.  This is very limited information so far about your nodes. 2.  The "mass" biopsy, contains some IDC.  This is the most commonly found kind of breast cancer.  Cancer cells are outside the duct so it's called infiltrating. There is no information about how much they saw. Again, this doesn't tell you much about size, so you really have no idea about how much invasive cancer is there.  It says the cells are moderately differentiated; this means they are Grade 2 or intermediate grade cells. 3.  Behind the areola they found an extremely tiny focus of IDC, also Grade 2.  Tiny is good, very good. 4.  In the top outside quarter of the breast they found some cancer cells, and calcifications inside the duct, also Grade 2.  This means the cancer is contained and hasn't spread outside the duct.  This is good.  Again they don't say anything about size.  The other things they found like fibrocystic change, adenosis, etc. are not cancer. These fine needle biopsies give you very preliminary information.  What are your next steps?

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2010 04:13PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:16AM by Gitane shelbytroy,  You need to rely on what your doctors are telling you.  They have the experience to put it all together for YOU.  So, that said, here's how I interpret what I have found through my research. What does an intermediate Oncotype indicate for an ILC patient?  It puts us in a category where they don't know what will/won't help us in terms of treatment.  It is NOT HELPFUL.   1.  Untreated, an intermediate has about the same prognosis as a high.  It's our "possible" response to endocrine therapy and lower rate of proliferation that separates us out as having a better outcome. (Our relapse may be later rather than in the first 5 years as is more frequent for high)  Not everyone with ER+ BC will respond to endocrine therapy and those who respond initially may become resistant later.  This is especially true for Tamox.  which may not be as effective as AI's. 2.  Oncotype scores, by their own research, are not prognostic beyond 5 years, and slow growing tumors (like ILC usually) are more likely to relapse after that time frame. 3.  ILC does not necessarily act like IDC.   Oncotype may not be as accurate for ILC, especially in terms of response to treatment. In fact, ILC has never been studied in terms of Oncotype and response to treatment.  Some research indicates that classical ILC (Grade 1) is less likely to have a pathologic complete response to chemo.  This does not mean that ILC patients are not helped by chemo. So, where does that leave us?  Traditional prognostic factors indicate that Grade 2 tumors greater than 1 centimeter should be offered chemo. even if the nodes are negative.

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2010 02:34PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:21AM by Gitane Kathleen,  I think it is possible to have your slides sent to another pathologist,  not in your same network/facility, to have them re-read.  I think you could start by calling a major facility, such as M D Anderson in Texas or Sloan-Kettering in NY, and telling them what you want to do, ie. have the slides and reports reviewed and get a second opinion.  They will be able to guide you.  I think all insurance will pay for a "second opinion", but I'm not sure how it works if treatment has already begun.  It might just be to help decide on treatment.  Anyway, I don't think it is too late to get another opinion, or even change oncologists.  I hope others who know more about this, and there are many on this site, will help you.  Just keep asking your questions, on other threads, until you get your answers.  Don't feel that there is something wrong with you for wanting to know more.  Your health is very, very worth following up on.  It seems like we need to give ourselves a crash course in breast cancer when we are least able to cope with stuff.  We have been where you are, and we understand.  Write to us, ask, and ask again.  Hugs.

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2009 01:55AM Gitane wrote: I have read that it would take between 300 to 600 slides to sample an entire breast.  It is just too time consuming and expensive and labs don't do it.  I think standard practice is to make multiple slides of the primary lesion and surrounding tissue, sample the skin, nipple and areola, then take random samples from the other quadrants of the breast.  Multiple sections are also done on lymph nodes.  Slides are kept at the pathology dept. for 10 years in most hospitals.  Frozen sections are not routinely kept except as part of research protocols.  I think that's how it is.  However, others probably know more.  Seems that having more tissue stored would be to our benefit, especially for future biomarker testing for new treatments or genetic studies.

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2010 01:15AM Gitane wrote: loving_mother,  Most of us got all the diagnostic information from our pathology reports.  There is information here on this site about reading the pathology report.  These are written after our surgeries (lumpectomy or mastectomy, sentinel lymph node biopsies and/or axillary lymph node dissection), usually, but some of the information can come from biopsies, too.  If you have had these procedures, there should be pathology reports, you can ask your doctors for copies and ask your doctors to explain everything in the reports.  The pathology will tell you what kind of breast cancer you have.  IDC (invasive ductal carcinoma) and ILC (invasive lobular carcinoma) are the most common types.  If there was cancer within the ducts or lobules as well these are called "in-situ carcinoma" which means the cancer is contained and has not spread into the stroma of the breast, DCIS (ductal carcinoma in-situ) LCIS (lobular cancer in-situ).  The cancer cells may have receptors on them, ER (estrogen receptors) PR (progesterone receptors).  If the cells have these receptors it means they may be more likely to respond to an endocrine therapy like Tamoxifen or an Aromatase Inhibitor.  Without receptors the cancer cell would not respond to these treatments.  Another test is for Her2.  If cells overexpress Her2 protein or the Her2 gene is amplified, the cancer may respond to Herceptin, without Her2 Herceptin doesn't help.  My doctors used a PET/CT scan (or they may order a PET scan) to see if the cancer had spread to any organs.  If there is a cancer deposit that is very small, though, the scan won't probably see it.  Also, to check the bones, a bone scan is used.

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2009 02:35PM Gitane wrote: From my MRI after neoadjuvant chemo I may have had a pCR, but after the mastectomy the pathologist could see viable cancer still in the breast.  I'm not sure anything short of surgery can assure you of a pCR, even if the surgery is a lumpectomy of the former tumor site.  For this reason a clip is often placed in the tumor before neoadjuvant therapy, so the surgeon will know exactly the site of the tumor if it disappears.

Posts.Content: May 14, 2009 05:43PM Gitane wrote: Oh, Judy0, I do identify with you.  The sadness and fear that come with this diagnosis can be too much to bear at times.  Sometimes I feel that my type of cancer is so rare, the presentation was so unusual, there was so much tumor, the treatment probably won't work, etc., etc.  I wanted them to know better than to give me HRT, I wanted them to see it earlier (It was on my mammo 2 years before it was diagnosed.), I wanted them to know my prognosis, I wanted them to have a cure, I wanted them to care.  Ultimately, I realize what I want and what I get are very far apart.  Sometimes I drive myself, and people I love, crazy with this.  Then I feel guilt, shame, overwhelmed.  I wonder why I can't grow up, be grateful it was caught and I was treated, get over it, etc.  Because other major tragedies have happened to close family members, and other major life events have happened to me as well, it has taken years, but I'm starting now to get where I can let it go, do other things, and even start to feel more alive and happy.  The strong, sad, emotion comes back, of course, but less frequently and doesn't last as long. In my opinion the transition can't be rushed.  We are all different.  I know women who haven't taken nearly as long to adjust as I have, but that's them.  I am me.  You are you.  I wish you many more healthy, happy years of life.  I hope you will be coming back here to share what's happening, knowing that we all understand and care.  We are sisters.

For me they do exactly what you have described.  They do blood work, physical exam, and of course watch for symptoms.  I didn't get scans at all, and frankly, I'm just as glad not to get them.  However, some people ask for them if they have unusual symptoms that last more than 2 weeks and oncologists are usually pretty good about doing scans then. Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2010 11:42PM Gitane wrote: I, too, experienced very sad times, depression, for at least 4 years.  What has helped me more than anything else is finding two books that helped me understand better why the moods/feelings had me spiraling down into depression.  These are not books to just read but also give you steps you can take to help yourself.  The first one is the one that helped me the most with my unhappiness because it focuses specifically on depression, while using parts of the program presented in the second one.  The second one, however, is very important because it goes into much more detail.  I have been reading these and using them daily for about 2 years now.   The Mindful Way Through Depression, Freeing Yourself from Chronic Unhappiness, by Mark Williams, John Teasdale, Zindel Segal, and Jon Kabat-Zinn  Full Catastrophe Living, by Jon Kabat-Zinn  Everybody is different.  There is no set timeline, or path that anyone should take.  Our feelings are important, and there is nothing wrong with us for having them.  We just need to learn ways to keep them from taking over.  It can be done.  Hugs, G.

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2008 12:46AM Gitane wrote: daisyhope,  I have been through exactly what you are describing.  Nothing anybody could say or do made me feel better.  It seemed that my emotional mind had reached some kind of limit, and it scared me more than anything has ever done.  This kind of fear is very hard for us to take.  We need to find a way to get through it, but it's tough.  I would drive far away from everyone and sob like my heart would break, or just scream in rage until there was no energy left.  I can't tell you how much that is not like me.  I'm such a quiet, shy type of person.  When it got to be more than I could stand I asked for help.  My doctor prescribed an antidepressant. I took it for about 10 months.  I also met with a breast cancer therapist who helped me learn ways to calm myself, but honestly I didn't think it helped then, it's helping more now. Walking helped a lot.  Staying busy doing anything, didn't matter what, helped.  I think time helps the most.  It seems that trying to work right now is too hard, can you get time off until your emotions can level off?  Can you find a way to avoid the wine?  It's a temporary relief, but ultimately makes you even more vulnerable to the emotions you are having.  The roller coaster ride is something we all have endured, and continue to endure to some extent, though the highs and lows become much less extreme.  Above all know that you are a good, normal person and you are in the middle of a very extreme situation. Nobody is all that brave, we are all scared.   Give yourself all the gentle understanding you can, don't judge your actions, thoughts, or emotions too harshly.  Let the whole thing roll over you, pick yourself up, and move on to the next day.  Come here and talk a lot.  Or don't.  There is no right way to do this.  Lots of love.

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2008 11:49PM Gitane wrote:  Chemo was in the cards for me. I didn't have much nodal involvement, 1 mm micromet, but I had lots of tumor in my breast.  My oncologist said that ILC may not respond that well sometimes to chemo, but pleomorphic lobular cells are very much affected by it.  I am glad I got AC (4 infusions, 2 weeks apart) because I had better than 95% reduction in tumor by MRI.  Pathology showed some individual cells left, unfortunately, so I had 2 more AC infusions after surgery.  I have since found out my oncotype dx score was 23, I consider that high,  that my ER level was lower than shown previously by IHC, and that I was slightly in the PR+ range, but just barely.  I have read that tumors with low levels of ER and/or PR respond better to adriamycin.   I have read that the proliferation (mitotic) rate of the tumor being high can cause the Oncotype dx recurrence score to be high.  Also, Her2+ tumors sometimes get high RS scores. Anyway,  I agree that Adjuvant! adds information to the Oncotype DX score, and the oncologist's experience will undoubtedly count for a great deal in helping make the decision for or against chemo, and/or adriamycin.

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2010 04:41AM Gitane wrote: I happened to be reading your discussion and it reminded me of an article I read.  It is from the College of American Pathologists where they discuss the new guidelines labs will follow beginning 2011 to be sure the ER and PR measurements are accurate and standardized.  Very interesting discussions are within the article if you don't mind plowing through it.  The people here are the leaders in the field and it's interesting to read what they say.  I'll copy some of it here. On one point, everyone agrees: Current ER/PgR testing, regardless of how accurate it is, doesn’t tell the whole story. “For all practical purposes,” says Dr. Osborne, “having a correct positive ER or PgR result doesn’t guarantee that the hormonal therapy will work.” "And, says University of Michigan oncologist Daniel Hayes, MD, another co-author of the guideline, the benefit seen from hormonal therapy seems to level off at about 30 percent to 50 percent positivity. “A patient is not more likely to benefit if her tumor has 100 percent positive cells versus 50 versus 30.” " This is where you can read it.  Sorry I am unable to paste a link. http://www.cap.org/ Making ER/PgR practices toe the line Feature Story

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2010 12:11AM Gitane wrote: When I listen to the presenters at the teleconference they seem to be saying that in postmenopausal women recurrence risk is lowered 29% with Zometa.  In premenopausal women over 40 who had their estrogen production shut down by Goserlin there was also a 30% recurrence risk reduction with Zometa.  In women younger than 40 it seems Goserlin does not lower their estrogen levels enough for Zometa to be effective on its own.  I understand them to say that their hypothesis is that estrogen deprivation kills some cells and that the effect of Zometa on the bone microenvironment may keep remaining cells from getting the growth factors they need to survive and spread.  It seems that women under 40 may need an ooph and/or some other mechanism beyond Goserlin to stop all estrogen production in their bodies in order to benefit from Zometa.  This is what I am understanding from what I have heard and read so far.

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2008 04:44PM Gitane wrote: Hi Moody,  You can ask your doctor for a copy of your Oncotype DX test results if you want them.  They are yours, after all.  You can go to the Oncotype DX website to see a sample copy of a report to compare with the one you were shown.  The score was developed based on the recurrence statistics for different study populations.  The score is not the same as a percent of risk.  For example, a score of 25 may give you a 15% risk of recurrence in the first 10 years.  There is information on this that should have been given to you or mailed to you if you had this test done.  This information is also available on the Oncotype DX website. www.genomichealth.com/oncotype...

Each year in the U.S., approximately 127,000 women develop ER+ breast cancer, and an increasing percentage of these are specifically diagnosed with invasive lobular breast cancer. " "This study continues a string of discoveries the researchers have made regarding tamoxifen resistance. They had earlier found that invasive lobular breast cancer has many more so-called "gamma" estrogen-related receptors than the typical "alpha" estrogen receptors that tamoxifen was designed to inhibit. Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2011 02:48PM - edited Jun 17, 2011 02:49PM by Gitane I had the test done by Rational Therapeutics on my residual breast tumor cells after 4 rounds of AC.  By that time the tumor cells were resistant to everything they tested except AC.  It was still responding to that at an "intermediate" response level, so I had 2 more rounds of AC.  Had the testing not been done, the plan was for 12 weekly rounds of Taxol.  The testing showed the cells were resistant to Taxanes, so I'm pretty sure I was saved from a probably useless chemo and saved the Taxane SE's.  They test chemo combinations as well as individual chemos.   I think this is a very useful test.  There is a bad side to it, too, knowing that after 4 rounds of AC my tumor cells had developed resistance to almost everything available.  That's a bit hard to take.   G.

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2012 09:56PM Gitane wrote: (((Torridon))),   I don't know if this will help you, but I will share what I have learned.  Your body has been damaged and chemically altered by your treatments.  If you are on a hormonal, it is being continuously chemically altered by that.  It's a very big deal.  It has also been assaulted by your surgeries.  Don't underestimate the impact.  Under your thinking brain is an emotional layer that is, as you said, screaming.  It is looking for logical reasons why you are spinning out of control (past experiences/present and future losses, plain old survival instinct), but remember emotions aren't logical, they just are!  You need to heal, your body needs to recover from the assaults and adjust to the drugs you may be taking. You need to live in this void for a while so this can happen.  It helps to let the emotions come as they will.  They will come in waves, and pass. It's scary but letting them come and go helps them to slowly lessen in intensity. Your emotions are on overload.  You cannot think your way out of that! There are ways to look at your thinking, what your mind is doing, that help you observe this and be able to let it go. We do not have to let the "helpless, hopeless" messages we get inside become our reality.  Meditation, Yoga, guided imagery, body scans, relaxation techniques taught at the cancer centers are great.  You can learn these and they can help you the rest of your life.  There is nothing wrong with meds, too, to get you over the roughest patches.  Then there is the ever present fear and sadness.  Over time we are somewhat surprised to find that gradually, with no effort on our part, that starts to move over and allow something else.  However, it takes time.  That's also hard for us to allow.  At least it was for me.  I was so sad, so very sad.  I didn't know any way to handle it at the time and it took over my life.  I hit bottom about a year after I completed treatment.  It took me so long because I didn't know what to do and didn't ask for any help.  I've learned since that there are things I could have done, am doing now, that help me.  You are normal.  It's just so hard sometimes. Hugs,  G.

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2008 11:49PM - edited Sep 4, 2008 11:54PM by Gitane LisaF,  The questions you are asking are the same as mine.  I found this on the web. These are the presentations that were made at the Southwest Oncology Group Meeting this spring.  There is a slide that is part of the presentation made by Kathy Albain.  The title on the slide is "Comparison of CAF-T to Tamoxifen Alone,  DFS adjusted for nodal Status"  It shows SWOG 8814 patients DFS rates broken down by Oncotype DX RS and for "First 5 Years" and "Greater than 5 Years"  Looking at this slide it appears that Low RS patients treated with Chemo benefit from that chemo treatment in the "Greater than 5 Years" period just like the Intermediate and High RS groups.  If you get a chance to look at this, tell me what you think. https://swog.org/Visitors/Plenary0805.asp Group Meeting   The following presentations were given at the Plenary Session of the Spring 2008 Group Meeting in Atlanta, Georgia, "Southwest Oncology Group Showcase 2008." They are in Windows Media Video format, and should automatically start in the default player for .wmv files on your computer when you click the icon at the right of the presentation title.  SWOG-8814: Prognostic and predictive value of the 21-gene recurrence score assay in postmenopausal, node-negative, ER-positive breast cancer (SWOG-8814, TBCI-0100)  Kathy S. Albain, M.D. Professor of Medicine, Hematology and Oncology, Loyola University, Maywood, Illinois

Posts.Content: May 21, 2009 04:37PM - edited May 21, 2009 04:44PM by Gitane Tumor Markiers - in blood samples are using monoclonal antibodies to measure proteins (antigens) given off by the MUC1 gene. I think this gene is associated with immune response and the protein is found on/in many different types of breast cancer cells. In each individual it is different.  Tumor markers change over time, serial measurements; it's the percent of change in a given time that has to be interpreted by the oncologist.  Tumor markers are not reliable in 1/3 or more of us.  If they are going down or disease is stable that has to be good news.

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2010 11:03PM Gitane wrote: This link is to a teleconference held by the presenters of this data at the 2010 SABCS on December 9 (updated on December 10).  It has links to the slides they presented as well as an interview.  What I found most interesting was the overview of the difference between the study populations in the ABCSG trial and the AZURE trial.  The presenter slides from the Austrian group make a strong case for the efficacy of Z. acid in premenopausal patients being treated with endocrine therapy.  There is also a slide showing the different effect in the Austrian trial on women below 40 years of age and those above 40 years of age.  Finally, I noticed in one slide of the AZURE trial that Z acid lead to a reduction of 5% in bone mets in the overall population.  I don't know if this was only in postmenopausal women or not.  I couldn't tell. http://www.aacr.org/home/public--media/multimedia-/aacr-podcasts/ctrc-aacr-2010-sabcs-teleconferences-and-podcasts/results-of-the-azure-trial-teleconference.aspx I'm sorry I am unable to paste a link here,  my computer just won't do it.
